author: By Pete Tosiello
title: There’s Something Fishy About This Refuge in the Colorado Wilds
description: “The Guide,” by Peter Heller, evokes a near future in which coronavirus variants have pushed America’s leisure class to the great outdoors.
content: THE GUIDEBy Peter Heller
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: A 1,400-Mile Walk to Turkey Only to Be Told to Turn Back
description: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, August 24, 2021.
content: “It would have been better to stay and die in Afghanistan than make this journey.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: How to Find the New York Times Crossword Large Print and Other Solving Tools
description: We want the changes to our games to be easy to navigate.
content: The large print, ink saver and left-handed solving formats are all important functions to our solvers, and we realize that it may be hard to find them since changes were made to the Crossword web game.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Troy Closson
title: Woman Says R. Kelly Made Her Have Sex With Someone Else as Punishment
description: The second accuser to testify against the R&B star during his trial was once among his vocal supporters, but she said on Tuesday that Mr. Kelly had instructed her to lie.
content: She had broken one of R. Kelly’s rules, and as her punishment, the singer directed her to freshen up at a hotel, “put on something skimpy” and have sex with someone he called “Nephew,” the woman told jurors on Tuesday, her second day of testimony at Mr. Kelly’s trial.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Veronica Chambers
title: A Triumphant Debut Novel on Black History and Coming of Age in the South
description: In “The Love Songs of W.E.B. Du Bois,” by Honorée Fanonne Jeffers, history is everything — an inheritance of secrets, lies, talents, betrayals, ambition, accomplishment and possibility.
content: THE LOVE SONGS OF W.E.B. DU BOISBy Honorée Fanonne Jeffers
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonah E. Bromwich and Jan Ransom
title: An ‘Absolute Emergency’ at Rikers Island as Violence Increases
description: A federal monitor said that staff shortages had led to a sharp deterioration in conditions at the jail complex over the summer.
content: A detainee was stabbed. A correction officer was slashed. And another person who was incarcerated at Rikers Island had scalding water thrown on him, causing second-degree burns all over his body.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel E. Slotnik
title: The timelines for F.D.A. approval for the Moderna and Johnson & Johnson vaccines remain unclear.
description: Attention turns to the other two Covid vaccines available in the United States after the Pfizer-BioNTech vaccine got full federal approval for use in people 16 and older. Moderna applied for full approval in June, a month after Pfizer, and Johnson & Johnson is expected to apply soon.
content: Now that the Pfizer-BioNTech coronavirus vaccine has been given full federal approval for use in people 16 and older, attention is turning to the vaccines made by Moderna and Johnson & Johnson.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Fandos
title: The House passed a major voting rights measure, but it has a steep path in the Senate.
description: Named for civil rights icon John Lewis, the bill is narrower than the Democrats’ sweeping elections overhaul that has stalled in the Senate, but faces similar obstacles.
content: The House voted on Tuesday to restore federal oversight of state election laws, beginning a push by Democrats to strengthen the landmark Voting Rights Act of 1965 amid a national fight over access to the ballot box.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Jason Karaian, Sarah Kessler, Stephen Gandel, Lauren Hirsch, Ephrat Livni and Anna Schaverien
title: More Vaccine Mandates
description: The F.D.A.’s full approval of the Pfizer-BioNTech coronavirus shot gives companies more cover to require vaccinations for workers.
content: The F.D.A. granted full approval to the Pfizer-BioNTech coronavirus shots for people 16 and older yesterday, the fastest vaccine approval in the agency’s history. (Although, perhaps, not fast enough.) President Biden seized on the moment. “If you’re a business leader, a nonprofit leader, a state or local leader, who has been waiting for full F.D.A. approval to require vaccinations, I call on you now to do that,” he said. “Require it.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Jacobs
title: Met Opera Reaches Deal With Orchestra, Paving Way for Reopening
description: The labor deal means that the company, the largest performing arts organization in the nation, is on track to reopen next month after the pandemic kept it closed for more than a year.
content: The Metropolitan Opera has struck a labor deal with its orchestra, officials announced Tuesday, paving the way for its musicians to return to work and for the company, the largest performing arts organization in the nation, to resume performances next month after being shut down for more than a year by the pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clay Risen
title: Nashville’s Twisting Journey
description: The city has expanded rapidly — but that growth has done a number on its politics.
content: Sign up here to get On Politics in your inbox on Tuesdays and Thursdays.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Bahr
title: Sara Bareilles on the Lessons of Pema Chodron and the Joy of 10-Mile Walks
description: The 41-year-old singer-songwriter is back on Broadway in September for her fourth starring turn in “Waitress.”
content: Sara Bareilles is not finding her return to “Waitress” as easy as pie.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roni Caryn Rabin
title: Vaccines prevented fewer infections as Delta emerged, federal researchers find.
description: A study that followed essential workers in six states found that vaccine protection dropped from 91 percent to 66 percent, still a “really high number,” one scientist said.
content: Coronavirus vaccines provided strong protection against infection for essential workers earlier this year, but became less effective as the highly contagious Delta variant became the dominant form of the virus, according to a study published on Tuesday by federal health officials.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: F.D.A., Not F.D.R.
description: One chose bureaucratic caution. One didn’t.
content: The F.D.A.’s full approval of Pfizer’s Covid-19 vaccine is already making a difference. Within hours of the announcement yesterday, the Pentagon and several large companies and universities announced new vaccine mandates. President Biden, speaking at the White House yesterday afternoon, urged other organizations to follow: “Require your employees to get vaccinated or face strict requirements,” he said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Iva Dixit
title: Raw Onions Are the Best Food. Let Me Explain.
description: There’s no greater pleasure than biting into a slice of a raw red onion and tasting its stinging sharpness.
content: Eight years ago, I spent my first 48 hours in the United States being driven around the New Jersey suburbs by an acquaintance of my father’s. In his eagerness to familiarize me with the superiority of his (and now my) surrogate nation, he took particular care to show me the fundamental institutions that, according to him, made America great: the colossal gates granting entry to New Jersey’s very own Mycenae, the Woodbridge outlet mall; a Dunkin’ doughnut shop; the tube outside a drive-in TD Bank that sucks in checks. Pride shimmered in his eyes, but he grew increasingly irritated when I could not muster much enthusiasm for iced coffee and doughnuts. (I did not have it in me to tell him that Dunkin’ also has outposts in New Delhi, the city I left behind.) It was not until I came face to face with a tower of grenade-size red onions while browsing the organic-produce section at a Wegmans later that day that I felt my detachment toward this new country begin to ease a little.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Derrick Bryson Taylor
title: A wildfire in Minnesota is behaving like a ‘freight train,’ a fire official said.
description: The fire, in the northeastern portion of the state near the Canadian border, has burned more than 19,000 acres and is zero percent contained.
content: A fast-moving wildfire in northeastern Minnesota has drawn hundreds of firefighters and prompted a wave of evacuations since it started nine days ago.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Aronow and Doug Mennella
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: TUESDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melvin I. Urofsky
title: A Supreme Court That Has Gone Wrong
description: Erwin Chemerinsky’s “Presumed Guilty” details the many ways the Supreme Court has favored the police over the accused.
content: PRESUMED GUILTYHow the Supreme Court Empowered the Police and Subverted Civil RightsBy Erwin Chemerinsky
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: This Sophisticated Midwestern Tonic Makes a Bitter Statement
description: Gentian root, a centuries-old bittering agent, takes center stage in Gentiana from Top Note, a Milwaukee drink mixer company.
content: Added to bottled soft drinks since the late 19th century, gentian root has a long history as a bittering agent. At Top Note, a drink mixer company founded in Milwaukee by Mary Pellettieri, a craft beer maker, and her business partner, Noah Swanson, gentian takes center stage in Gentiana, a sophisticated new tonic. It’s the first in the company’s Bartender Release series. Lip-smacking on its own, it is excellent with gin or white rum. The pale amber tonic is not as tart as the company’s classic tonic water and more pointedly bitter than its excellent Indian tonic water.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Higgins
title: Montenegro Pledges to Stamp Out a Deadly Trade: Cigarette Smuggling
description: Investigators and journalists were killed while trying to expose smugglers. Now the country is cracking down on a trade it once protected.
content: BAR, Montenegro — Smoking kills, but the millions of cigarettes that slipped through the concrete warehouses of Montenegro’s main port on the Adriatic Sea were particularly lethal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michelle Goldberg
title: How Can Colleges Handle Sexual Misconduct Cases More Fairly?
description: In “Sexual Justice,” Alexandra Brodsky, a civil rights lawyer, homes in on the processes by which such cases are typically adjudicated — and how to improve them.
content: SEXUAL JUSTICESupporting Victims, Ensuring Due Process, and Resisting the Conservative BacklashBy Alexandra Brodsky
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephanie Rosenbloom
title: What to Do This Summer: Portland, Maine
description: Streets lined with galleries and shops. A working harbor. Outdoor dining at award-winning restaurants. The fleeting summertime pleasures of Longfellow’s childhood home await.
content: It was 1846 and the poet Henry Wadsworth Longfellow was walking around Portland, Maine, his boyhood home, when he stopped and, as he wrote, “listened to the lashing, lulling sound of the sea just at my feet. It was a beautiful afternoon, and the harbor was full of white sails, coming and departing.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Kenigsberg
title: ‘Kipchoge: The Last Milestone’ Review: Skipping Ahead
description: This documentary about the Kenyan runner Eliud Kipchoge takes a victory lap for an athletic feat.
content: Never cut the course at a marathon, but you could probably skip the first half-hour of “Kipchoge: The Last Milestone” without missing much. A tribute to the pathbreaking Kenyan runner Eliud Kipchoge, this documentary sets out to show how, in 2019, he became the first person in history to run a marathon distance in less than two hours.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shawn Hubler
title: How Did Larry Elder Become a Front-Runner in California’s Governor Race?
description: Mr. Elder, a conservative radio host who paints himself as the native son of a simpler and safer California, has drawn criticism from Democrats and Republicans alike.
content: SACRAMENTO — For a generation, Larry Elder has been an AM radio fixture for millions of Californians, the voice they could count on when they were fed up with liberal Democratic politics. Undocumented immigrants? Deport them. Affirmative action? End it. Equal pay? The glass ceiling doesn’t exist.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Coral Murphy Marcos
title: Workers making Oreos and other Nabisco snacks are on strike in five states.
description: A bakery union and the snack food giant’s corporate parent, Mondelez International, are at odds over shift lengths, retirement benefits and other issues.
content: Unionized workers who make Oreos, Chips Ahoy!, Newtons and other Nabisco snacks are on strike in five states over what they say are unfair demands for concessions in contract negotiations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Tracy
title: Ebony Returns to Chronicle a New Moment
description: A leading publication covering Black life in America has emerged from bankruptcy with a new owner and ambitious plans.
content: Growing up in Louisville, Ky., Eden Bridgeman Sklenar leafed through issues of Ebony and Jet at the beauty salon, where she would go with her mother every week to get her hair styled in tight curls.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear, Annie Karni and Eric Schmitt
title: Biden says the U.S. is poised to meet the Afghan withdrawal deadline, at least for now.
description: The president reiterated his desire to complete the mission by the deadline, but he said withdrawal will hinge on completing the goal of airlifting all Americans and Afghan allies out of the country.
content: President Biden said on Tuesday that the United States was on track to end its two-decade military involvement in Afghanistan by his Aug. 31 deadline.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kwame Anthony Appiah
title: My Roommates Have Been Listening to My Therapy Sessions. Is That OK?
description: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on an invasion of privacy and reporting misconduct at work.
content: My therapist is no longer seeing patients in person, so I’ve been attending therapy sessions at home in my room. Recently, one of my roommates told me that she had been listening to my sessions for weeks and heard me mention her name and the name of our other roommate. Now both roommates have told me I will not be allowed to have my sessions in the apartment anymore. They asked me to do them in a coffee shop or the public library (which is still closed in my city because of Covid). I could get a white-noise machine, but at this point I’m scared that they may hear a part of my session and gang up on me again.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erin Woo
title: TikTok adds in-app shopping, in a partnership with Shopify.
description: In a pilot program, merchants will be able to add a shopping tab to their profiles and link to products within posts on the video app.
content: TikTok and Shopify, the e-commerce platform, said on Tuesday that they were working together to add the ability for consumers to shop directly in the TikTok app for the first time.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gaiutra Bahadur
title: Kat Chow on How Mourning Is Like Taxidermy
description: In her memoir “Seeing Ghosts,” the author recounts her mother’s death and her immigrant family’s numerous migrations, separations and losses, evoking the way grief entails a particular, perpetual sorrow.
content: SEEING GHOSTSA MemoirBy Kat Chow
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor
title: Michael Avenatti Is Granted Mistrial in Federal Fraud Case
description: A U.S. District Court judge found that federal prosecutors had withheld financial data from Mr. Avenatti, the former lawyer for the pornographic film actress Stormy Daniels. He faces a retrial.
content: A federal judge in Southern California declared a mistrial on Tuesday in a fraud case against Michael Avenatti, giving the brash former lawyer for Stormy Daniels a rare victory as he fights his conviction and sentence in another criminal case and awaits trial in a third.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michelle Cottle
title: The Trump Clown Car Has a Smashup in Arizona
description: The misbegotten Republican recount of Arizona's 2020 election results is an object lesson about the embarrassing damage to democracy by a sore loser.
content: Monday was supposed to be a banner day for former President Donald Trump and the MAGAverse. After multiple delays, legal challenges and public controversies, the results of the third — and hopefully final — review of the presidential voting in Maricopa County, Ariz., was scheduled for delivery to its Republican sponsors in the State Senate. At long last, the proof of mass election fraud would be laid out for all to see! Mr. Trump would be vindicated! Maybe even reinstated!
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dan Levin
title: Oregon brings back an outdoor mask mandate for both vaccinated and unvaccinated people.
description: Gov. Kate Brown said the contagiousness of the Delta variant of the coronavirus made the step necessary, and called masks a critical tool to keep people safe.
content: Oregon is restoring a statewide mask mandate, ordering both vaccinated and unvaccinated people to wear masks when gathering indoors or out.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Whet Moser and Amelia Nierenberg
title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
description: The senior vaccination gap is making the Delta wave deadlier.
content: The U.S. has a far higher share of older adults without full vaccine protection than many other wealthy countries, and it has made the Delta wave deadlier.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Jackson
title: The Climate Crisis Is Worse for Women. Here’s Why.
description: Although climate change is a collective problem, its burdens — displacement, homelessness, poverty, sexual violence, disease — weigh more heavily on women and girls.
content: — Katharine K. Wilkinson, a co-editor of the climate anthology “All We Can Save”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Cochrane
title: House Passes $3.5 Trillion Budget Plan for Vast Expansion of Safety Net
description: Democratic leaders had to haggle their way to passage, committing to moderates that there would be a vote on the $1 trillion bipartisan infrastructure plan by Sept. 27.
content: WASHINGTON — A divided House on Tuesday approved a $3.5 trillion budget blueprint that would pave the way for a vast expansion of social safety net and climate programs, as Democrats overcame sharp internal rifts to advance a critical piece of President Biden’s ambitious domestic agenda.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Spencer Bokat-Lindell
title: How OnlyFans Became the Latest Casualty of the War on Porn
description: Companies like Mastercard are cracking down on adult content. Are they doing more harm than good?
content: This article is part of the Debatable newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it on Tuesdays and Thursdays.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roni Caryn Rabin
title: Overweight Adults Should Be Screened for Diabetes at 35, Experts Say
description: Nearly one in seven Americans now has diabetes, a record rate. The condition also raises the risk of severe illness after coronavirus infection.
content: Overweight adults should be screened for Type 2 diabetes and abnormally high blood sugar levels starting at age 35, five years earlier than currently advised, an expert task force recommended on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Livia Albeck-Ripka and Muktita Suhartono
title: Indonesia is easing restrictions gradually as cases fall.
description: Indonesia, where cases of the coronavirus surged last month, will gradually ease restrictions in the capital, Jakarta, and elsewhere as reports of new cases decline.
content: Indonesia, where cases of the coronavirus surged last month, will gradually ease restrictions in the capital, Jakarta, and elsewhere as reports of new cases decline.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shira Ovide
title: A Thumbs Down for Streaming Privacy
description: The streaming apps and devices we pay for aren’t necessarily careful with our personal information.
content: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. Here is a collection of past columns.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Motoko Rich
title: Emperor Naruhito, whose family has long supported the Paralympics, will formally open the Games.
description: The Imperial Family’s support goes back to the 1964 Paralympics, which were held in Tokyo.
content: TOKYO — His Majesty the Emperor of Japan, Naruhito, will officially declare the Paralympic Games open. Japan’s Imperial family has a long history of support for the Paralympics: The current emperor’s parents, Emperor Emeritus Akihito and Empress Emerita Michiko, adopted the 1964 Paralympics in Tokyo as one of their primary causes when they were Crown Prince and Princess. Tokyo is the first city to host the Paralympics twice.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eshe Nelson
title: Airbnb says it will give temporary free housing to 20,000 Afghan refugees.
description: The company said it was working with resettlement agencies. It did not specify how long refugees could stay in the apartments and houses.
content: Airbnb and its charitable arm, Airbnb.org, said on Tuesday that the company intended to provide free temporary housing globally for 20,000 refugees fleeing the Taliban’s takeover of Afghanistan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Troy Closson
title: Is New York’s Wave of Gun Violence Receding? Experts See Reason for Hope.
description: Shootings are still well above prepandemic levels. But this summer has been considerably less violent than last.
content: Dozens of people were gathered outside on a recent Sunday night, listening to music and partying in the Bedford-Stuyvesant neighborhood of Brooklyn, when two men walked up and opened fire, wounding eight. Ten minutes later, three teenagers were shot nearby in Cypress Hills. And the same night, three men in their 20s were wounded by gunfire in Springfield Gardens, Queens.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexis Soloski
title: Review: In ‘Islander,’ the Puck Stops Here
description: This verbatim hockey drama considers issues of masculinity and the peculiar ownership that fans feel toward a team and its players.
content: The 2017 season didn’t start too badly. The New York Islanders, a National Hockey League team with a new coach and a newish berth at the Barclays Center in Brooklyn, might have allowed a few too many shots on goal, but they still won most of their games. A couple of months later, in December, it all began to go wrong. Then it went more wrong. The defense fell apart. The team missed the playoffs. John Tavares, the Islanders’ captain and star player, departed for the Toronto Maple Leafs. Fans revolted.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Cullen
title: Your Wednesday Briefing
description: Biden sticks to his deadline on Afghan exit.
content: President Biden told world leaders during a virtual meeting that he was still planning for U.S. troops to leave Afghanistan by Aug. 31, though an extended mission was a possibility, according to an official.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roni Caryn Rabin
title: Caught in the Crossfire Over Covid’s Origins
description: Alina Chan suggested last year that the coronavirus was “pre-adapted” to humans. Critical reaction was swift and harsh.
content: In the early days of the pandemic, scientists reported a reassuring trait in the new coronavirus: It appeared to be very stable. The virus was not mutating very rapidly, making it an easier target for treatments and vaccines.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth Paton
title: Luxury’s Gray Market Is Emerging From the Shadows
description: New platforms and dealers able to offer steep discounts on the latest styles are becoming a powerful — and disruptive — force in the fashion industry.
content: Imagine you are hunting online for a pair of square-toed slides from Bottega Veneta, one of the most-hyped luxury brands of the moment. A new season pair can cost more than $550 from the brand’s website, an old-guard department store like Neiman Marcus or a newer e-commerce player like Net-a-Porter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marisa Meltzer
title: Big Bold Gold
description: Gloppy, glamorous and gold, Mondo Mondo is a jewelry brand for an expressive moment.
content: “I just like the sound of it,” Natasha Ghosn said about naming her jewelry and fragrance brand Mondo Mondo. “I was thinking of Mondo films, Italian, kitschiness and campiness.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim McKeough
title: A Derelict Warehouse as a Second Home?
description: Even his artsy friends were skeptical. But for $70,000, he knew he could find a way to make it work.
content: When Michael Northrup began fantasizing about buying a derelict fruit-processing and storage facility in Tieton, Wash., as his second home, even his design-savvy friends weren’t sure what to think.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Seth Colter Walls
title: A Composer Shows the Way to Give Classical Music Swing
description: Interest has been building in the works of Nikolai Kapustin, who wrote in classical styles, with a jazzy spin.
content: Back in 1936, savvy listeners may have sensed that the novelty tune “Rhythm Saved the World” wasn’t only about its nominal subject: the drummer boys who motivated Revolutionary War soldiers at the Battle of Bunker Hill. No, as played by Louis Armstrong, it was clear that the song’s real subject was jazz itself, and its ability to conquer foreign lands — and other genres — with ease.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Fabi
title: How’d You Do That?!
description: Jessie Bullock and Ross Trudeau perform an animated duet.
content: TUESDAY PUZZLE — Oh my goodness, I have so many feelings about this puzzle! For one thing, the story in Jessie Bullock and Ross Trudeau’s constructor notes made my shriveled Grinch heart grow at least six sizes. Congratulations to these two lovebirds on both their co-constructed New York Times Crossword and their co-constructed future together!
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luis Ferré-Sadurní
title: Hochul Is Sworn In: ‘I Want People to Believe in Their Government Again’
description: Kathy Hochul, who is the first woman to serve as New York’s governor, has vowed to usher in a new era of civility and consensus in state government.
content: ALBANY, N.Y. — Kathleen C. Hochul became the first woman to ascend to New York’s highest office on Tuesday, vowing to usher in an era of civility and consensus in government, following the decade-long reign of her disgraced predecessor, Andrew M. Cuomo.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Gilded Candles to Brighten Your Dinner Table
description: Let these fair-trade sets from South Africa add a warming glow to your space.
content: Perhaps you’re starting to do a little entertaining, maybe planning a modest dinner party. To add a beautiful glow to the table are these gilded candles, new to GlobeIn, an online market that features wares from artisans around the world. They’re nine inches tall and come in sets of two for $13, a price at which lighting them and watching them diminish would not be cause for deep regret. The patterns vary. The candles are made by Kapula, a fair-trade company in South Africa that specializes in decorative candles.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Arash Azizzada
title: This Is What the Afghan Evacuation Looks Like on the Inside
description: In the absence of American guidance, it has fallen to volunteers to figure out how to rescue Afghans scrambling for their lives.
content: The day our lives fell apart, Sunday, Aug. 15, I received a call from a close friend in Kabul. Usually cool and confident, vital skills for a community leader in a complex, conflict-ridden place like Afghanistan, my friend now whispered in desperation. “I need to get out,” he said. “Help me.” In the background, I could hear the city bustling nervously as millions of people absorbed the fact of the Taliban’s conquest.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Recipes for Rosh Hashana, and for Every Day
description: In “The Essential Jewish Baking Cookbook,” Beth A. Lee offers an easygoing but detailed book of sweet and savory treats.
content: Beth A. Lee, a food blogger who digs deep into family recipes (her own and others’), has organized some of them into “The Essential Jewish Baking Cookbook,” an easygoing but detailed book of sweets and savories for holidays and every day. Topping the special occasion list is Rosh Hashana, the Jewish New Year, which begins this year — 5782 — at sundown on Sept. 6. Apples are a symbol of the holiday on the Ashkenazi table, and the book features recipes for a cake studded and topped with them and bits of ginger. A very basic challah recipe and the whole-wheat version are included without directions for shaping the bread round, instead of braided, as is customarily done for the holiday. Rather, challah rolls with apple filling make suitable stand-ins, and the dough can be used to make one large loaf. The recipe for pletzel, a Polish specialty that’s also called onion board, deserves to be added to your flatbread collection. The book taps traditions, including those of Sephardic and Mizrachi cultures, in addition to Ashkenazic. It also gives details on making the recipes kosher.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sabrina Tavernise, Clare Toeniskoetter, Jessica Cheung, Austin Mitchell, Neena Pathak, Anita Badejo, Larissa Anderson and Chris Wood
title: Why Mexico Is Suing U.S. Gunmakers
description: Mexican officials have long complained about the role that lax U.S. gun control has played in bloodshed in their nation. Now they are taking their arguments to a U.S. federal court.
content: For years, Mexico has been gripped by horrific violence as drug cartels battle each other and kill civilians. In the last 15 years alone, homicides have tripled.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Proudfoot
title: He Blew the Whistle on the Catholic Church in 1985. Why Didn’t We Listen?
description: As an investigative reporter, Jason Berry exposed the church’s systematic cover-up of sexual abuse. Somehow, it wasn’t enough.
content: Nearly 20 years ago, an investigation by The Boston Globe into sexual abuse by Roman Catholic priests ignited a firestorm of scandal that has traveled around the world. For many Americans, these shocking revelations — especially of the related cover-ups by the church — came out of nowhere, almost like a bolt of lightning. But the sobering reality is that this bolt of lightning had been striking for at least 15 years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Norimitsu Onishi and Sharif Hassan
title: Under Taliban Rule, Life in Kabul Transforms Once Again
description: Though the streets are quiet, Kabul residents describe a struggle to make ends meet in a reeling economy where banks and government offices are closed, and uncertainty reigns.
content: The Americans are all but gone, the Afghan government has collapsed, and the Taliban rule the streets of Kabul now. Overnight, millions of Kabul residents have been left to navigate an uncertain transition after 20 years of U.S.-backed rule.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Josh Holder and Amy Schoenfeld Walker
title: The U.S. has more unvaccinated seniors than other wealthy countries, making Delta deadlier.
description: The United States has a far higher share of seniors without full vaccine protection than many other wealthy countries, a key risk factor driving serious Covid-19 illness and death, a Times analysis shows.
content: The United States has a far higher share of seniors without full vaccine protection than many other wealthy countries, a key risk factor driving serious Covid-19 illness and death, a Times analysis shows.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Bar Benno Opens in the Former Leonelli Restaurant and Bar Space
description: Northern Thai on the Upper East Side, an expansion for a Park Slope, Brooklyn, brew pub, and more restaurant news.
content: Now that it’s time to begin reopening his restaurants in the Evelyn Hotel in NoMad, the chef Jonathan Benno and his partners decided to do more than simply turn the key. In the space that was Leonelli Restaurant and Bar, they’ve pivoted from Italian to French, with the bar, tables and an open kitchen dedicated to bistro fare, and changed the name to Bar Benno. The elegant flagship Benno, which has three stars from The New York Times, in the back of the space will not change, except to feature more seafood when it’s ready for diners in a month or so. But now, fitted with a huge back bar and a U-shaped counter with seating, the new spot, called Bar Benno, will feature a cold seafood selection, and hors d’oeuvres like escargots, egg in a potato crust, pâté de campagne, and Basque-style tripe on its classic menu. Main courses include rotisserie chicken, steak au poivre and bourride, a rich Provençal seafood stew rarely seen on New York menus. Fries will come alongside steamed mussels, a French dip sandwich and steak tartare. From 5 to 7 p.m., with aperitifs and cocktails, there will be savories like deviled eggs with caviar, salmon rillettes, white anchovies with bread and butter, and fried pig’s trotter with sauce gribiche. “I didn’t feel it was enough just to reopen as we were before,” Mr. Benno said. “I’ve been cooking French most of my whole career, so I’m very comfortable with this. Fortunately, we did not have to do a big renovation.” Mr. Benno also said that it was difficult for Leonelli Restaurant and Bar, an Italian taverna, to establish its own personality. But, he said, offering bistro fare in a space that’s something of a prelude to the Benno dining room and that leans toward France made more sense. A taste of Italy with flatbread pizzas, breads and pastries remains available in Leonelli Bakery in the front of the building. (Opens Friday)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Fandos
title: House Passes a Voting Rights Bill, but a G.O.P. Blockade Awaits in the Senate
description: Named for the civil rights icon John Lewis, the bill is narrower than the Democrats’ sweeping elections overhaul that has stalled in the Senate, but faces similar obstacles.
content: The House voted on Tuesday to restore federal oversight of state election laws under the 1965 Voting Rights Act and expand its reach, as Democrats moved to strengthen a crowning legislative achievement of the civil rights era amid a renewed national fight over access to the ballot box.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tom Coughlin
title: Nothing Could Prepare Me for Watching My Wife Slip Away
description: I’ve spent my life preparing for the biggest games a person could play, but nothing prepares you to be a caregiver who has to watch a loved one slip away.
content: Someone recently asked me why my wife, Judy, isn’t in any of the photos from our Jay Fund Foundation events, and it was with a heavy heart that I had to explain. For the past year, I’ve been torn between protecting my wife’s dignity and privacy and sharing some deeply personal and sad news. It’s only after some reflection that I’ve come to the conclusion that what my family and I are experiencing may be helpful for others to read.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kathleen Kingsbury
title: He Won Super Bowls. Now He’s a Full-Time Caregiver.
description: Tom Coughlin, a former head coach of the New York Giants, on caring for his wife, Judy.
content: This article also appears in the Opinion Today newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it in your inbox each weekday morning.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yunte Huang
title: The Worldwide Effort to Bar Chinese Immigration
description: Mae Ngai’s “The Chinese Question” looks at an issue that has disturbed the Anglophone world for decades, and continues to produce divisions today.
content: THE CHINESE QUESTION
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick Kingsley and Isabel Kershner
title: New Israeli Leader Backs Hard Line on Iran but Softer Tone With U.S.
description: In an interview before meeting with President Biden, Prime Minister Naftali Bennett said he opposed U.S. efforts to restore a nuclear deal with Iran and ruled out peace talks with the Palestinians.
content: JERUSALEM — Prime Minister Naftali Bennett, speaking days before his first meeting with President Biden as Israel’s new leader, said he would oppose American-led attempts to reinstate a lapsed nuclear agreement with Iran and continue Israel’s covert attacks on Iran’s nuclear program.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Helene Cooper and Eric Schmitt
title: Military Ramps Up Evacuations From Kabul, but Bottlenecks Persist
description: The Pentagon has increased the number of flights, but questions remain about whether the military can sustain the pace as the deadline to end the operation draws near.
content: WASHINGTON — With the Aug. 31 deadline for a U.S. withdrawal from Afghanistan rapidly approaching, the Pentagon has sharply ramped up the speed of evacuations from the Kabul airport, flying out 21,600 people in 24 hours, Defense Department officials said Tuesday. But bottlenecks in the system, and President Biden’s insistence that all troops leave the country by the end of the month, may prevent the military from keeping that pace.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sandomir
title: Buckie Leach, Coach of U.S. Gold Medal Fencer in Tokyo, Dies at 62
description: Under his tutelage, Lee Kiefer became a first for the United States. Leach led the women’s national foil team in five Summer Olympics. He died in a motorcycle accident.
content: Buckie Leach, an elite fencing coach who guided the first American woman to win an individual Olympic medal in the foil competition, a gold at the Summer Games in Tokyo last month, died on Aug. 14 in a motorcycle accident in Pennsylvania. He was 62.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rebecca R. Ruiz and Tariq Panja
title: FIFA, Deemed a Victim of Its Own Scandal, Will Share $200 Million Payout
description: Soccer’s governing body and two affiliates in the Americas have been awarded tens of millions of dollars seized by the Department of Justice.
content: Even as top soccer officials were still being arrested as part of a sprawling corruption investigation in 2015, lawyers for the sport’s global governing body and U.S. prosecutors began to embrace an intriguing premise:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Wagner
title: The Padres Wanted the World Series. Will They Make the Playoffs?
description: A young core of superstars and a few high-profile additions were supposed to take San Diego to the next level. A bad stretch has the team looking for someone to blame.
content: The San Diego Padres, once one of the most exciting teams in baseball but now sputtering badly, produced the type of victory on Saturday that its players had been craving, one they hoped signaled that the tide was finally turning.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zolan Kanno-Youngs
title: In Southeast Asia, Kamala Harris’s Message: You Can Count on the U.S.
description: The vice president rebuked China and sought to fortify the image of the United States as a credible ally amid growing questions about Afghanistan.
content: SINGAPORE — Vice President Kamala Harris sought to fortify the image of the United States as a credible ally by offering a sharp rebuke of China during an address on Tuesday in Southeast Asia. Her effort comes as the White House faces growing questions about its reliability as an international partner amid continuing violence in Taliban-controlled Afghanistan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mihir Zaveri
title: Kathy Hochul Becomes New York’s Governor
description: Ms. Hochul is now the state’s first female governor, taking leadership at an extraordinary time for New York.
content: [Want to get New York Today by email? Here’s the sign-up.]
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rick Rojas, Tariro Mzezewa and Jamie McGee
title: Tennessee City Searches for Flood Victims While Grappling With All It Has Lost
description: At least 18 people are dead and three others remained missing after catastrophic flash floods. Officials attributed the devastation to a “perfect storm” of perilous conditions.
content: WAVERLY, Tenn. — The search for the missing after violent floods tore through Middle Tennessee pressed ahead with renewed urgency on Tuesday even as the authorities acknowledged diminishing hope for finding alive the last of those still unaccounted for.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michelle Goldberg
title: The Afghanistan War Was Lost Before Biden Ended It
description: Leaving is disastrous. Staying would have been, too.
content: In 2019, allied and government airstrikes in Afghanistan killed some 700 civilians, more than in any other year since the war’s start, according to the Costs of War Project, a group working to tally the human toll of America’s post-9/11 conflicts. U.S. and NATO airstrikes declined in 2020 after Donald Trump’s withdrawal agreement with the Taliban, but strikes by the Afghan Air Force increased.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Summer Reading Contest Winner, Week 9: On ‘The Best Way to Respond to Text Messages’
description: Thank you to the teenagers who participated this week, and congratulations to our winner, Bloomy, as well as our many runners-up and honorable mentions.
content: We received 1,074 entries from students from around the world for the ninth week of our 10-week Summer Reading Contest. Thank you to everyone who participated, and congratulations to our winner, Bloomy, as well as the runners-up and honorable mentions we recognize below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Rappeport
title: The World Bank is freezing aid disbursements to Afghanistan.
description: The bank had committed nearly $800 million to the country in 2021.
content: WASHINGTON — The World Bank said on Tuesday that it had halted disbursements of aid money to Afghanistan as it assesses how the Taliban plan to rule the country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anahad O'Connor
title: Should I Be Worried About R.S.V. in My Child?
description: Respiratory syncytial virus is showing an unusual summer surge.
content: I heard that a new virus called R.S.V. is spreading among children. As a parent, should I be worried?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ellen Barry
title: Massachusetts is set to issue a mandate for masks in schools, a reversal for the governor.
description: Gov. Charlie Baker has come under pressure from teachers’ unions, doctors, lawmakers and activists for not backing a mask mandate.
content: Massachusetts is preparing to introduce a mask mandate for the state’s public schools as early as Wednesday, in a reversal for Gov. Charlie Baker, who has vocally advocated local control of school masking policy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kristen Bayrakdarian
title: Recent Commercial Real Estate Transactions
description: Recent commercial real estate transactions in New York.
content: $3.16 MILLION
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ruth Maclean and Mady Camara
title: Hissène Habré, Ex-President of Chad Jailed for War Crimes, Dies at 79
description: Mr. Habré, who received a life sentence for crimes against humanity including torture and sex offenses, was said to be out of prison for medical treatment at the time of his death.
content: DAKAR, Senegal — Hissène Habré, the former president of Chad, has died while serving a life sentence for crimes against humanity, including killings, torture and sex offenses, during his rule in the 1980s. He was 79.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Sisario
title: Charlie Watts, the Unlikely Soul of the Rolling Stones
description: In a band that defined debauched rock ’n’ roll, he was a quiet, dapper jazz fan. But their unusual chemistry defined the rhythm of the Stones, and of rock.
content: On some superficial level, Charlie Watts had always seemed the oddest Rolling Stone, the one who never quite fit as a member of rock’s most Dionysian force.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick Kingsley and Adam Rasgon
title: In Shift, Israel Quietly Allows Jewish Prayer on Temple Mount
description: Jewish activists say they are exercising their right to free worship at a site holy to Jews and Muslims. But the change upsets a longstanding compromise aimed at staving off conflict.
content: JERUSALEM — The Israeli government has long forbidden Jews to pray on the Temple Mount, a site sacred to Jews and Muslims, yet Rabbi Yehudah Glick made little effort to hide his prayers. In fact, he was livestreaming them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tiffany May
title: International students begin to return to U.S. universities after a Covid hiatus.
description: After a precipitous drop in international student enrollment in 2020, the number of American student visas granted to international students has recovered to levels preceding the coronavirus pandemic.
content: After a precipitous drop in international student enrollment in 2020, the number of American student visas granted to international students has recovered to levels preceding the coronavirus pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Susan Dominus
title: He Was the ‘Perfect Villain’ for Voting Conspiracists
description: Eric Coomer had an election-security job at Dominion Voting Systems. He also had posted anti-Trump messages on Facebook. What happened next ruined his life.
content: It was already late on Nov. 9 when Eric Coomer, then the director of product strategy and security for Dominion Voting Systems, left his temporary office on Daley Plaza in Chicago and headed back to the hotel where he’d been staying for the previous few weeks. Both the plaza and the hotel had the eerie post-apocalyptic feel of urban life during the pandemic, compounding the sense of disorientation and apprehension he felt as he made his way up to his room.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Niraj Chokshi
title: Boeing is under F.A.A. scrutiny over reports that it may hamper oversight.
description: A regulatory official cited concerns about interference with employees assigned to ensure that the company follows safety rules.
content: The Federal Aviation Administration is looking into Boeing’s corporate culture, which an agency official said “appears to hamper” Boeing employees responsible for providing oversight, raising safety concerns and otherwise representing the agency’s interests.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gavin Edwards
title: Charlie Watts, Bedrock Drummer for the Rolling Stones, Dies at 80
description: Mr. Watts, who had no taste for the life of a pop idol, was an unflashy but essential presence with the band and brought to it a swinging style.
content: Charlie Watts, whose strong but unflashy drumming powered the Rolling Stones for over 50 years, died on Tuesday in London. He was 80.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David E. Sanger and Michael D. Shear
title: Eager to Shift Narrative, Biden Team Puts Airlift in Historical Context
description: In describing evacuation efforts, President Biden has referred to the Berlin airlift more than 70 years ago, in which food was flown into a city whose access had been choked off by the Soviet Union.
content: When President Biden briefly referred to the Berlin airlift — the operation 73 years ago to feed a city whose access had been choked off by the Soviet Union — in describing the United States’ evacuation efforts in Afghanistan, he was revealing the inspiration for a broader plan to redeem his messy exit.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natalie Kitroeff
title: Biden Faces a Trade-Off: Stop Corruption, or Migration?
description: President Biden promised to attack corruption in Central America head on, but that goal has taken a back seat to cooperating on stopping migrants from the region.
content: The testimony was explosive: In June, a witness told Guatemala’s top anticorruption prosecutor that he had gone to the president’s home and delivered a rolled-up carpet stuffed with cash.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Derrick Bryson Taylor
title: The Caldor fire is ‘knocking on the door’ to the Lake Tahoe basin, a fire official said.
description: In response to several fires around California, Gov. Gavin Newsom on Monday requested a Presidential Major Disaster Declaration to assist in wildfire response and recovery efforts.
content: The Caldor fire near Sacramento has become the No. 1 priority for scores of firefighters who have been tackling blazes around California after it quickly burned more than 100,000 acres in 10 days, a fire official said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sharon LaFraniere and Noah Weiland
title: F.D.A. Fully Approves Pfizer-BioNTech’s Vaccine, a First for a Covid-19 Shot
description: The move was expected to kick off a round of new vaccination mandates from hospitals, schools and private companies.
content: WASHINGTON — The Food and Drug Administration on Monday granted full approval to Pfizer-BioNTech’s coronavirus vaccine for people 16 and older, a decision that is likely to set off a cascade of vaccine requirements by hospitals, colleges and universities, corporations and other organizations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sabrina Imbler
title: A Shifting Climate Gave Humans Many Opportunities to Leave Africa
description: A new paleoclimate model finds many favorable windows when Homo sapiens might have survived a migration out of Africa.
content: Until recently, scientists believed modern humans left Africa in one enormous exodus around 65,000 years ago. But a new climate model suggests that modern humans had several windows of opportunity to leave the continent far earlier.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Gold
title: New York’s governor calls for a school mask mandate, and for teachers to face vaccine rules.
description: Gov. Kathy Hochul said she would partner with “all levels of government” to implement a vaccine order.
content: Gov. Kathy Hochul, in her first day as governor of New York State, called on state health officials to impose a universal mask mandate in public and private schools and said she wanted to institute Covid vaccine-or-test mandates for employees in schools.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deb Amlen
title: Wordplay’s Freelance Writing Guidelines
description: What we look for, and how to pitch to us.
content: Please note that our freelance commissions are reportage, not personal essays like our Solver Stories feature. Submission guidelines for Solver Stories are here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ashley Wong
title: Andrew Cuomo Loses His Emmy on Same Day He’s Replaced as Governor
description: The International Academy of Television Arts and Sciences rescinded the award Mr. Cuomo received for his pandemic briefings, citing the sexual harassment allegations against him.
content: In the latest blow to his legacy, former Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo of New York has been stripped of the Emmy Award he received last year for his popular briefings on the coronavirus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melina Delkic
title: Your Tuesday Briefing
description: Turkey blocks an influx of Afghan refugees.
content: Weeks before Kabul fell to the Taliban, tens of thousands of Afghans were already fleeing their country each week. Many of them traveled 1,400 miles across Iran, hoping to make their way to Europe. But the migrants were met with sharp resistance at Turkey’s border, with thousands waiting in Iran’s border region.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Remy Tumin
title: Afghanistan, Budget, Charlie Watts: Your Tuesday Evening Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
content: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bret Stephens
title: Our ‘Broken Windows’ World
description: The end of Pax Americana is an invitation to chaos.
content: For years, “broken windows” policing — the idea that the best way to prevent serious crime was to enforce laws against petty crime — was derided by critics as unnecessary, unjust, even racist. So cities across America pulled back from prosecuting the supposedly small stuff, like shoplifting.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jamelle Bouie
title: The 9 Democrats Making Nancy Pelosi’s Life Harder Are Making a Big Mistake
description: The point of winning is to use your power well. Then you might actually get to keep it.
content: Popular or unpopular, good economy or bad, the president’s party almost always loses seats in midterm elections. That there are so few exceptions — Franklin Roosevelt and the Democrats in 1934, Bill Clinton and the Democrats in 1998, and George W. Bush and the Republicans in 2002 — proves the rule.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John McWhorter
title: The Performative Antiracism of Black Students at the U. of Wisconsin
description: A textbook demonstration of the difference between sincere activism and playacting.
content: The University of Wisconsin has apparently done Black people a favor. It lifted away a rock.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sima
title: Looks Like Bird Dung. But It’s Really a Predatory Spider.
description: Many creatures use mimicry to hide from predators. This one also uses it to lure in prey.
content: It almost sounds like a playground taunt: You look like bird poop and smell like it too.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Vineyard
title: Rosie Perez Hates Flying, but She Soared in ‘The Flight Attendant’
description: The HBO Max show brought the veteran performer her first acting Emmy nomination. “To be recognized now, at my age, for something that I did just for the art of it all?” she said. “That really moves me.”
content: Voting is underway for the 73rd Primetime Emmys, and this week we’re talking to several first-time Emmy nominees (at least for acting, in this case; Rosie Perez had been previously nominated, but as a choreographer). The awards will be presented Sept. 19 on CBS.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sergio Olmos, Mike Baker and Alan Feuer
title: Even Amid a Crackdown, the Proud Boys Are Still Agitating
description: At least two dozen members of the Proud Boys face federal charges in the U.S. Capitol siege. But on Sunday, members of the group were mobilizing once again in Oregon.
content: PORTLAND, Ore. — In the months since the siege at the U.S. Capitol in January, federal investigators have looked closely at the Proud Boys, a far-right nationalist group at the forefront of the riot. Agents have pried into the group’s encrypted messages, pored over video footage of their exploits and built criminal cases against at least two dozen members.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ed Morales
title: Larry Harlow, a Salsa Revolutionary
description: The musician, who died on Friday, was a true originator of the genre. An outsider, he lived a Latin music life by immersing himself in Afro-Caribbean culture.
content: In many ways, Larry Harlow — one of the central figures of salsa and its defining label, Fania Records — was a master at mixing the diverse musical connections between New York and the Caribbean. In a career that spanned six decades, he stitched together overlapping genres like rock, jazz and R&B and various Cuban genres like rumba, son and guaracha through intimate, soulful knowledge of both musical traditions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Blinder
title: A.C.C., Big Ten and Pac-12 Form Coalition to Counter SEC’s Might
description: The move was far short of a merger and came less than a month after Oklahoma and Texas said they would leave the Big 12 for the SEC.
content: In search of a way to curb the Southeastern Conference’s swelling power, three of the wealthiest college sports leagues — the Atlantic Coast, Big Ten and Pac-12 conferences — said Tuesday that they had formed a coalition to navigate a turbulent era.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ruth Maclean and Mady Camara
title: Chad’s former president, jailed for crimes against humanity, is dead. Reports cite Covid.
description: Hissène Habré, the former president of Chad, has died while serving a life sentence for crimes against humanity, including killings, torture and sex crimes, during his rule in the 1980s. He was 79.
content: Hissène Habré, the former president of Chad, has died while serving a life sentence for crimes against humanity, including killings, torture and sex crimes, during his rule in the 1980s. He was 79.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Malia Wollan
title: How to Let Your Mind Wander
description: Research suggests that people with freely moving thoughts are happier. Easy, repetitive activities like walking can help get you in the right mindset.
content: “Sometimes you just want to let your mind go free,” says Julia Kam, a cognitive neuroscientist who directs the Internal Attention Lab at the University of Calgary. Kam became interested in her subject 15 years ago as an undergraduate struggling with her own distracted thoughts during lectures. “I came into the field wanting to find a cure,” she says. But the deeper she got into research, the more she came to appreciate the freedom of an unfocused mind. “When your thoughts are just jumping from one topic to the next without an overarching theme or goal, that can be very liberating,” she says.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Simon
title: Prepping for the Year of Many, Many Weddings
description: After much holdover, nuptials are back on for 2022 and invites are piling up. But just because you’re ready to get out and celebrate doesn’t mean your wallet is.
content: When the third wedding was added to our 2022 calendar, I was delighted to have another joyful event after a year and half of small, limited celebrations. When the sixth friend’s “We’re engaged!” announcement appeared on my Instagram feed, I worried but shrugged it off. After all, why spend energy thinking about all those logistics when my fiancé and I were busy planning our own 2022 wedding, anyway?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ian Prasad Philbrick
title: Where Is the Anti-Biden Tea Party?
description: An analysis of crowd events shows the president hasn’t yet drawn the protests that Barack Obama and Donald Trump faced.
content: Barack Obama had been president for only a few months when the Tea Party roared onto the American political scene. Conservative activists rallied and organized by the hundreds of thousands against his economic stimulus plan and health care reforms. Their efforts torqued the Republican Party rightward and powered its gains in the 2010 midterm election.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Das and Tariq Panja
title: Premier League Won’t Release Some Players for September World Cup Qualifiers
description: The decision sets up a confrontation with FIFA, which can order the players’ release. Spain’s league said it would support any of its teams that followed suit.
content: The Premier League said Tuesday that its clubs would not release any players for travel to so-called red list countries during soccer’s September international break, a brazen rejection of protocol that sets up a significant confrontation with the sport’s governing body, FIFA.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Transcript: Ezra Klein Interviews Bessel van der Kolk
description: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode with Bessel van der Kolk. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.
content: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode with Bessel van der Kolk. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Soumya Karlamangla
title: How High Vaccination Rates Are Protecting Parts of California
description: Counties with above-average levels of vaccination have some of the lowest Covid-19 hospitalization rates.
content: The Food and Drug Administration granted full approval to the Pfizer-BioNTech coronavirus vaccine on Monday, paving the way for more employers, schools and other organizations to mandate the shots.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Grace Cook
title: The Cotton Tote Crisis
description: You can get cotton bags pretty much everywhere. How did an environmental solution become part of the problem?
content: Recently, Venetia Berry, an artist in London, counted up the free cotton tote bags that she had accumulated in her closet. There were at least 25.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trish Bendix
title: Jimmy Fallon Celebrates the F.D.A.’s Full Approval of a Covid Vaccine
description: “It’s about time,” Fallon said. “Their statement started with, ‘Hey, sorry, I just saw this.’”
content: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By ‘The Ezra Klein Show'
title: This Conversation Will Change How You Think About Trauma
description: The author of “The Body Keeps the Score” on how trauma transforms the body and the brain.
content: “Trauma is much more than a story about something that happened long ago,” writes Dr. Bessel van der Kolk. “The emotions and physical sensations that were imprinted during the trauma are experienced not as memories but as disruptive physical reactions in the present.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eduardo Medina
title: Ohio State announces a vaccine mandate for students and employees.
description: U.S. regulators gave full approval for the Pfizer-BioNTech vaccine this week, giving schools and companies room to require vaccinations.
content: Ohio State University announced on Tuesday that all students, faculty and staff would be required to be vaccinated against Covid-19 during the fall semester, becoming one of the first large state universities to issue a vaccine mandate that extends beyond students.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julian E. Barnes and Richard Pérez-Peña
title: The C.I.A. director visited Kabul for secret talks with the Taliban.
description: The meetings are the highest-level in-person talks between a Biden administration official and Afghanistan’s new leadership.
content: WASHINGTON — The C.I.A. director, William J. Burns, traveled to Kabul for talks with the Taliban leadership, American officials familiar with his visit said on Tuesday, conducting the administration’s highest-level in-person talks so far with the new de facto leaders of Afghanistan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Fabi
title: Discover Unexpectedly
description: Adam Vincent gives the hard sell.
content: WEDNESDAY PUZZLE — Congratulations to Adam Vincent, for whom this puzzle marks a second appearance in the New York Times Crossword!
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cammie McGovern
title: Children With Disabilities Need Sex Ed Too
description: Special needs kids need lessons on healthy relationships as much as everyone else — maybe even more.
content: In 2018, an N.P.R. investigation sent shock waves through the community of people with intellectual or developmental disabilities, their families and their care providers: according to Department of Justice data, these people are at least seven times as likely to be the victims of sexual abuse as their nondisabled peers. Terrified parents like me have been grappling with this news ever since, unsure of what steps to take to best protect their children.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Wilson and Jesus Jiménez
title: Cuomo Commutes Sentences of 1981 Brink’s Robbery Participant and 4 Others
description: David Gilbert, who was serving a 75-year sentence for felony murder in the notorious Rockland County crime, will now be eligible for parole.
content: In the waning hours of his final day in office, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo commuted the prison sentence of one of the members of the gang behind the infamous robbery of a Brink’s armored car in 1981 that left two police officers and a guard dead, a politically motivated ambush that continues to reverberate 40 years later.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: How Not to Create Jobs
description: Punishing the unemployed doesn’t accomplish very much.
content: Last Friday, as the clock ticked toward 10 a.m., many labor economists were poised at their keyboards like runners about to do a 100-yard sprint. You see, the Bureau of Labor Statistics was scheduled to release its latest monthly report on state employment and unemployment, and everyone wanted to crunch the numbers and learn what they showed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Livia Albeck-Ripka
title: The C.D.C. adds several countries to a list that travelers should avoid.
description: The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention has updated its health advice for travel to six countries it now considers to be “very high” risk given the rapid spread of the coronavirus and the Delta variant. It is suggesting that people avoid traveling to these countries altogether, or if they must go, to get vaccinated beforehand.
content: The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention has updated its health advice for travel to six countries it now considers to be “very high” risk given the rapid spread of the coronavirus and the Delta variant. It is suggesting that people avoid traveling to these countries altogether, or if they must go, to get vaccinated beforehand.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Motoko Rich
title: Refugees lead the parade of athletes.
description: Alia Issa and Abbas Karimi carried the contingent’s flag, which bore the Paralympic symbol.
content: TOKYO — The parade of the athletes is always the centerpiece of the opening ceremony. At the Olympics, Greece typically marches in first, because it is the nation where the Olympics originated. As with the Olympics, the number of athletes in the Paralympic parade is likely to be diminished in comparison with a typical Games, because coronavirus restrictions prohibit athletes from entering the Paralympic Village until five days before their competitions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pete Wells
title: Searching for Italy at Tom Colicchio’s New Restaurant
description: Seasonal Italian cooking should be a natural move for the chef. But Vallata doesn’t quite get off the ground.
content: The problem with Tom Colicchio’s new restaurant, Vallata, isn’t the cooking, most of which is very good and some of which is wonderful. All of it is Italian, in a rustic trattoria style based on ingredients plucked from the Union Square Greenmarket, a few blocks from Vallata’s location on East 19th Street. “Colicchio cooks Italian” may not be a revolutionary idea, but at least it’s a coherent one that hasn’t been tried before.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Cramer and Isabella Grullón Paz
title: For States Dealing With the Spotted Lanternfly, the Policy Is No Mercy
description: The spotted lanternfly, an invasive species from Asia, is a voracious plant-eater and public nuisance that could cost state economies hundreds of millions of dollars.
content: Adorned with pale, pinkish gray wings, black dots and a scarlet undercoat, the spotted lanternfly is a beautiful insect.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Justin Torres
title: Stories of Our Perverse Present and Our Haunted Futures
description: “After the Sun,” a collection by the Danish writer Jonas Eika, stretches past the limits of the ordinary.
content: AFTER THE SUNBy Jonas EikaTranslated by Sherilyn Nicolette Hellberg
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Karni and Zolan Kanno-Youngs
title: A report of an unexplained ‘health incident’ in Hanoi delays Harris’s arrival.
description: The vice president’s flight to Vietnam was delayed after a report of a possible “anomalous health incident” in Hanoi. The term is used to refer to unexplained illnesses among State Department employees.
content: Vice President Kamala Harris was delayed Tuesday for more than three hours as she was departing from Singapore for Vietnam because of a report of a recent possible “anomalous health incident” in Hanoi, where she will discuss public health strategies and seek to bolster partnerships in the South China Sea, a crucial piece of President Biden’s strategy to counter the rising economic influence of China.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amy Haimerl
title: Creating Culture in a W.F.H. World: How 3 Small Businesses Did It
description: Flexible Fridays, employee empowerment and creative problem-solving all helped these companies bring on new workers during the pandemic.
content: The Siete Family Foods website, like most company websites, showcases its founders. But it also highlights almost all of the company’s 98 employees, featuring childhood photos and “two truths and a lie” for each person. The full staff would be listed, but Siete is growing too fast to keep up: It has added more than 30 employees during the pandemic, including three earlier this month.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Justin Gest
title: What the ‘Majority Minority’ Shift Really Means for America
description: The census should collect data about race. But we should stop obsessing over it.
content: In 2015, the Census Bureau published a report projecting that by 2044, the United States’ white majority would become merely a white plurality: immigration and fertility trends would lead to America’s ethnic and racial minorities outnumbering its white population.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Tiny Love Stories: ‘I Laughed Out Loud to Nobody in Particular’
description: Modern Love in miniature, featuring reader-submitted stories of no more than 100 words.
content: Earlier this year, I went out with someone who told me that chickens slept in trees. I refused to believe him, but our banter helped during a time when I was overwhelmed with grief from my grandmother’s passing. Things didn’t take flight with Chicken Man. Several months later, I spotted a fluffy white poof high up on a tree late one night. It was a hen I often see in my Singapore neighborhood. I laughed out loud to nobody in particular and thought of my grandmother, Chicken Man and how life affords us small moments of joy unexpectedly. — Shu Wen Chye
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Becca Rothfeld
title: The Fate of the Self in the Age of Clicks
description: In “God, Human, Animal, Machine,” the essayist and cultural critic Meghan O’Gieblyn traces how our conception of the human mind has been shaped by our tech-driven era — and what such a view leaves out.
content: GOD, HUMAN, ANIMAL, MACHINETechnology, Metaphor, and the Search for MeaningBy Meghan O’Gieblyn
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lara Jakes
title: How Many People in Afghanistan Need to be Rescued? The Number Remains Elusive.
description: U.S. officials are reluctant to provide an estimate of the one number that matters most in their stream of evacuation updates.
content: WASHINGTON — More than 70,700 people had been evacuated from Afghanistan as of Tuesday evening. Nearly 6,000 American troops are protecting the international airport in Kabul, the capital. And additional U.S. flights are leaving every 45 minutes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Simon Romero
title: A Texas Sheriff’s Grim Task: Finding Bodies as Migrant Deaths Surge
description: After working in oil fields, Oscar Carrillo eyed the stability of law enforcement or funeral work. As a border sheriff, he is doing both.
content: VAN HORN, Texas — Like many other West Texas sheriffs, Oscar E. Carrillo packs a gun, drives a truck and wears a cowboy hat.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim McKeough
title: The Stress-Free Way to Hang Art
description: Why does hanging art make many of us so nervous? If you follow a few simple rules, it’s easy.
content: Hanging art and other decorative items on the wall — one of the final steps in furnishing your home — should be fun. So why is it often a source of anxiety?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erin Griffith
title: They Still Live in the Shadow of Theranos’s Elizabeth Holmes
description: Female entrepreneurs said they were constantly compared to Ms. Holmes, the disgraced founder of Theranos, who faces trial soon.
content: SAN FRANCISCO — When Alice Zhang set out in 2018 to raise funding for her drug discovery start-up, investors kept asking her about Theranos, the blood testing start-up led by the entrepreneur Elizabeth Holmes that had collapsed in scandal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ramin Skibba
title: When the Big Bang Was Just a Theory
description: In “Flashes of Creation,” Paul Halpern offers a dual biography of George Gamow and Fred Hoyle, two midcentury physicists who debated the origins of the universe.
content: FLASHES OF CREATIONGeorge Gamow, Fred Hoyle, and the Great Big Bang DebateBy Paul Halpern
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Lyons
title: Watch This Fun Australian Drama and a Dark HBO Max Comedy
description: If you like juicy gossip or watching suburban parties implode onscreen, our TV critic has some shows for you.
content: This is a preview of the Watching newsletter, which is now reserved for Times subscribers. Sign up to get it in your inbox four times a week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nick Corasaniti
title: A top Republican in Pennsylvania promises to review the 2020 results as conspiracy theories flourish.
description: Jake Corman, the leader of the G.O.P.-controlled State Senate, signaled that the state would follow Arizona in bowing to falsehoods about voter fraud and re-examining results.
content: The top Republican in the Pennsylvania State Senate promised this week to carry out a broad review of the 2020 election results, a move that comes as G.O.P. lawmakers continue to sow doubts about the contest’s legitimacy by pushing to re-examine votes in battleground states like Arizona.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Lyall
title: A Human Cloning Error and Existential Questions Fuel This Science Fiction Romp
description: In Matthew FitzSimmons’s speculative murder mystery “Constance,” the title character’s consciousness is mistakenly downloaded into a clone.
content: If you’ve woken from a routine uploading of your consciousness into the computer at the local cloning clinic, the last thing you want to hear is that something has gone awry. For Constance D’Arcy, the title character in Matthew FitzSimmons’s new thriller, a hint that all is not well comes when, groggy and confused, she hears herself referred to as “it.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Protess and William K. Rashbaum
title: Giuliani Associate Expected to Plead Guilty to Campaign Finance Charge
description: Igor Fruman had aided Rudolph Giuliani in his effort to dig up dirt on Donald J. Trump’s political rivals.
content: Igor Fruman, a former associate of Rudolph W. Giuliani who helped him search for damaging information about Donald J. Trump’s political rivals, is expected to plead guilty next month in an unrelated campaign finance case, according to people with knowledge of the matter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Kara Swisher Live: A Times Virtual Event
description: Join the “Sway” podcast host, with guests Cori Bush and Maggie Haberman, as she unpacks the stories that matter now.
content: After a summer of budget negotiations, a sweeping infrastructure bill and a surge in coronavirus cases, what will fall in the United States bring? What are the stories that will matter the most in politics, media and tech? Where is power changing, and how do we make sense of it?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mihir Zaveri
title: What Challenges Does Gov. Kathy Hochul Face?
description: It’s a precarious time for the state, with challenges in public health, housing, education and infrastructure.
content: It’s a precarious time for the state, with challenges in public health, housing, education and infrastructure.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erica Ackerberg and Amy Padnani
title: Nothing Got in the Way of These Paralympians
description: With the Paralympics underway in Tokyo, we’re remembering the lives of athletes with a variety of disabilities around the world who found freedom in their sports.
content: With the Paralympics underway in Tokyo, we’re remembering the lives of athletes with a variety of disabilities around the world who found freedom in their sports.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aatish Bhatia and Nadja Popovich
title: These Maps Tell the Story of Two Americas: One Parched, One Soaked
description: The country, like most of the world, is becoming both drier and wetter in the era of climate change. It depends where you live.
content: The country, like most of the world, is becoming both drier and wetter in the era of climate change. It depends where you live.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Krauss
title: 4 Children’s Books to Read This Week
description: A selection of books published this week.
content: A selection of books published this week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Josh Holder and Amy Schoenfeld Walker
title: Many Older Americans Still Aren’t Vaccinated, Making the Delta Wave Deadlier
description: Compared with other highly vaccinated countries, large parts of the United States have many vulnerable seniors, helping spur hospitalization and death.
content: Compared with other highly vaccinated countries, large parts of the United States have many vulnerable seniors, helping spur hospitalization and death.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Rustic Italian With an Assist From Union Square
description: Greenmarket produce is at the heart of Tom Colicchio’s new restaurant, Vallata.
content: Greenmarket produce is at the heart of Tom Colicchio’s new restaurant, Vallata.
source.name: The New York Times

title: A Second Home Where He’s ‘Free to Play’
description: Even his artsy friends were skeptical when he bought the warehouse. But for $70,000, he knew he could find a way to make it work.
content: Even his artsy friends were skeptical when he bought the warehouse. But for $70,000, he knew he could find a way to make it work.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reuters and Storyful
title: Crews Battle Caldor Fire in California
description: The Caldor fire, which started near Sacramento, has burned more than 100,000 acres in 10 days and destroyed over 400 homes. It is one of several large fires currently burning in the state.
content: The Caldor fire, which started near Sacramento, has burned more than 100,000 acres in 10 days and destroyed over 400 homes. It is one of several large fires currently burning in the state.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: U.S. on Track for Aug. 31 Afghanistan Withdrawal, Biden Says
description: President Biden said that the U.S. was on track to complete evacuations and withdraw military forces from Afghanistan by Aug. 31, but that he had prepared military leaders to adjust the timetable “should that become necessary.”
content: President Biden said that the U.S. was on track to complete evacuations and withdraw military forces from Afghanistan by Aug. 31, but that he had prepared military leaders to adjust the timetable “should that become necessary.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Proudfoot
title: The First Report
description: As an investigative reporter, Jason Berry exposed the church’s systematic cover-up of sexual abuse. Somehow, it wasn’t enough.
content: As an investigative reporter, Jason Berry exposed the church’s systematic cover-up of sexual abuse. Somehow, it wasn’t enough.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Dibdin
title: 7 Fiction Podcasts Ready Made for Vacation
description: These scripted shows will keep you absorbed whether you’re traveling, enjoying a staycation or just trying to avoid following the news.
content: Audio drama engages the mind in a way no other kind of storytelling can. Listening to a story unfold through voices and sound effects alone, your brain is forced to fill in the visual blanks and dream the fictional world into being. This makes scripted podcasts a more active and immersive alternative to bingeing another streaming show — and, as a bonus, they’re usually free.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Using Mandates to Overcome Vaccine Resistance
description: Readers express increasing frustration and anger toward the holdouts, especially hospital workers. Also: Streaming stand-up comedy.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Aug. 24, 2021
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Tuesday, Aug. 24, 2021.
content: An article on Sunday about disorder in the U.S. exit from Afghanistan misidentified the date of a meeting among national security officials at the Pentagon. It was April 24, not April 28.
source.name: The New York Times
